raw_text:
John Peel replacement show begins
 
 The permanent replacement for late DJ John Peel's BBC Radio 1 show goes on air on Tuesday, with three hosts chosen to fill the legendary presenter's slot.
 
 Rock DJ Huw Stephens will go on air in the 2300 slot every Tuesday, with black music champion Ras Kwame on Wednesdays and dance DJ Rob Da Bank on Thursdays. Rob Da Bank filled in after Peel had a heart attack aged 65 in October. All three will play "diverse, unpredictable and non-commercial" songs under the banner of the OneMusic show.
 
 Radio 1 said the station was not trying to replace Peel, but would rise to the "challenge" of "keeping his legacy alive" with unpredictable music. The three DJs were chosen for their "in-depth musical knowledge across a variety of musical genres", the station said.
 
 Rob Da Bank is one of the hosts of The Blue Room, an early morning weekend show which plays electronic and dance music. Huw Stephens has been one half of the Thursday night show Bethan and Huw in Wales, which explores new music, especially up-and-coming acts in Wales. And Ras Kwame is host of 100% Homegrown on Radio 1's digital station 1Xtra, dedicated to showcasing the best hip-hop and garage. Another change to the station line-up will see Sara Cox return after maternity leave. She will host the lunchtime show on Saturdays from this week.
 
 Good luck to all three of them, not one DJ could fill Peels boots so it's probably a good idea to get them all contributing. This time next year I hope we are saying how well these DJs have done, but I fear this time next year we will really realise how much John Peel will be forever missed.
 
 Very good idea to continue the legacy without attempting to replace John Peel. Also, there will surely be a wider spectrum for international music as three top radio DJs unite under the One World name. Congratulations!
 
 The whole glory of John Peel was the fact he was not commited to one genre. He played what he liked across the range of music.... this is not going to be the same, and all they seem to be doing is what they already have. Bring back Steve Lamacq.
 
 The obvious heir to John Peel is the marvellous, wonderful and talented Claire Kember from totallyradio.com. This lady is young and fresh and is one of the most knowledgeable and likeable people in British broadcasting today. Everyone who listens to her show understands and compares her to the ledgendary John Peel. BBC Radio should seek out the real talent from internet radio stations, people who are making a real impact on the world of music and the world in general.
llama3.2:1b: The permanent replacement for John Peel's BBC Radio 1 show begins with three hosts: Huw Stephens on Tuesdays, Ras Kwame on Wednesdays, and Rob Da Bank on Thursdays.
The new show is called OneMusic and will play "diverse, unpredictable, and non-commercial" music under the banner of this name.
llama3.2:3b: The BBC Radio 1 show replacing John Peel will feature three hosts: Huw Stephens, Ras Kwame, and Rob Da Bank.
They will play "diverse" songs under the OneMusic banner, with each hosting their own night.
Sara Cox is also returning to host a Saturday lunchtime show.
gemma2:2b: John Peel's replacement show, OneMusic, features Huw Stephens (Tuesday), Ras Kwame (Wednesday) and Rob Da Bank (Thursday).
The DJs will play "diverse, unpredictable" music across genres.
Sara Cox returns to her Saturday lunchtime show.
The legacy of John Peel continues with a focus on unique musical exploration.
Some listeners express doubt about the new format's ability to live up to Peel's eclectic style and call for more innovative programming.
The suggestion is made to bring back Steve Lamacq as a possible alternative.

They will play diverse, unpredictable and non-commercial music under the banner of "OneMusic".

The station aims to keep Peel's legacy alive with unpredictable music.
Huw Stephens, Ras Kwame, Rob Da Bank, and Sara Cox are among those selected.

The show plays "diverse, unpredictable and non-commercial" songs under the OneMusic banner.
Huw Stephens and Rob Da Bank have previous experience with electronic and new music, while Ras Kwame specializes in hip-hop and garage.
Sara Cox returns on Saturdays from maternity leave.
Critics suggest this approach may not adequately replace Peel's eclectic style.
Alternatives like Claire Kember from internet radio are proposed as more fitting to continue the legacy.

The main objective is to bring back Steve Lamacq, the obvious heir to John Peel.
Everyone who listens to his show will understand and compare to the legendary John Peel.
BBC Radio should seek out the real talent from internet radio stations, people who are making a real impact on the world of music and the world in general.
smollm:1.7b: The summary is concise and objective, preserving key ideas and details while omitting unnecessary information.

The text focuses on the main points:

1.
John Peel replacement show begins with three hosts chosen to fill the late DJ's slot every Tuesday.
Rock DJ Huw Stephens will go on air in the 2300 slot every Tuesday, with black music champion Ras Kwame on Wednesdays and dance DJ Rob Da Bank on Thursdays.
The BBC Radio 1 station is not trying to replace John Peel, but rather rising to the challenge of keeping his legacy alive by playing a diverse range of music under the OneMusic brand.
Rob Da Bank is one of the hosts of 100% Homegrown on Radio 1's digital station 1Xtra, dedicated to showcasing the best hip-hop and garage from Wales.
Sara Cox returns after maternity leave as a new host for the lunchtime show on Saturdays from this week.
Good luck to all three of them, not one DJ could fill John Peel's boots so it's probably a good idea to get them all contributing.
This time next year I hope we are saying how well they have done, but I fear this time next year we will really realize how much John Peel was the real deal.
The whole glory of John Peel was the fact he was not committed to one genre.
He played what he liked across the range of music... this is not going to be the same, and all they seem to be doing is what they already have.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: The permanent replacement for DJ John Peel's BBC Radio 1 show begins next Tuesday, featuring three hosts: Huw Stephens on Tuesdays, Ras Kwame on Wednesdays, and Rob Da Bank on Thursdays.
They play diverse, unpredictable, and non-commercial songs under OneMusic's banner.
Rob Da Bank was a host of The Blue Room, which focuses on electronic and dance music, while Huw stepped in half a Bethan show as part of his Welsh series.
Ras Kwame is co-host for 1Xtra, showcasing hip-hop and garage.
Sara Cox returns from maternity leave to host the Saturday lunchtime show.
The trio aims to preserve John Peel's legacy by exploring various genres unpredictably.
tinyllama:1.1b: The BBC Radio 1 announced the appointment of three new hosts to replace late DJ John Peel, which began on November 20, 2021.

The permanent replacement for Peel's slot will be Rock DJ Huw Stephens, who will join with black music champion Ras Kwame and dance DJ Rob Da Bank in the "diversse, unpredictable, and non-commercial" genre of music under the OneMusic banner.
The announcement also revealed that two returning DJs from Peel's show, Saracox, and former Radio 1 host Sarala Cox, will contribute to the new weekday lunchtime show on Saturday afternoons.
A new change to the station lineup will see Sarala Cox return after her time-off in a bid to keep up with "new music" from Wales.
Additionally, the legacy of Peel is being honored by introducing three top radio DJs under OneWorld banner for a wider range of music, including international genres.

The appointment of Claire Keebler from Totally Radio.com as the new host of BBC Radio's "The Morning" program has become an obvious heir to Peel, and is being sought by the corporation after several other online stations have been identified for the job.
The announcement marks the beginning of a new era in radio, one that embraces the diversity of music and culture around the world, and will ensure that Peel's legacy continues to live on.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The news article mentions that a permanent replacement for late DJ John Peel's show will begin airing on Tuesday.
The hosts chosen to fill the legendary presenter's slot are Huw Stephens, Ras Kwame, and Rob Da Bank.
The three DJs have diverse musical knowledge across various genres, such as rock, dance, and unpredictable music.
The decision to not replace Peel was made following extensive research and consultation with industry professionals.
The new hosts will play "diverse, unpredictable, and non-commercial" songs under the banner of the One Music show.
This is in line with John Peel's legacy and the station's desire to rise to the challenge of keeping his musical legacy alive.

The appointment of Rob Da Bank as one of the hosts on The Blue Room, an early morning weekend show that plays electronic and dance music, demonstrates the station's commitment to diversifying its programming.
Additionally, Sara Cox will host the lunchtime show on Saturdays from this week.
The change in lineup has been met with mixed reactions among fans and industry professionals.
Some are praising the new hosts for continuing John Peel's legacy, while others believe that they represent a wider spectrum of international music compared to their predecessor, Huw Stephens.
Overall, the article presents a balanced perspective on the new broadcasting lineup and highlights the importance of preserving John Peel's legacy in the face of change.
phi:2.7b: A new chat system uses artificial intelligence assistant to provide concise and informative summaries of given texts.
The system is used by a curious user to understand the replacement show for late DJ John Peel's BBC Radio 1.

The system generates a summary that includes important details such as the names of the three hosts (Rock DJ Huw Stephens, black music champion Ras Kwame, and dance DJ Rob Da Bank), the type of songs they will play (diverse, unpredictable, and non-commercial) under the OneMusic show's banner, and the fact that this is not an attempt to replace John Peel but rather keep his legacy alive.
The system also provides information about the three hosts' previous experiences in the industry and their roles on other BBC Radio 1 shows.
Overall, the system generates a summary that accurately represents the content of the original text while providing useful insights for the user.

The station's OneMusic show will feature rock DJ Huw Stephens, black music champion Ras Kwame, and dance DJ Rob Da Bank, playing "diverse, unpredictable and non-commercial" songs under the banner of the OneMusic show.

The OneMusic show aims to keep Peel's legacy alive with unpredictable music.
The station emphasizes that it is not trying to replace Peel but rather "keep his legacy alive."
The three hosts were chosen for their in-depth musical knowledge across various genres.
Additionally, Sara Cox will return to host the lunchtime show on Saturdays after maternity leave.
Some readers criticize the new lineup for lacking the diverse range of music that Peel was known for and suggest other potential heirs to the legacy, such as Claire Kember from totallyradio.com.

Each DJ brings expertise in different genres—Stephens in new music, Kwame in hip-hop and garage, and Da Bank in electronic and dance music.
Listener reactions are mixed, with some praising the approach while others doubt it will match Peel’s eclectic style.

granite3.1-dense:2b: On Tuesday, BBC Radio 1 commences its new nightly show following the late DJ John Peel's departure.
The three chosen hosts—Huw Stephens, Ras Kwame, and Rob Da Bank—will air at 2300 on Tuesdays, Wednesdays, and Thursdays respectively.
Each host brings diverse musical expertise: Huw Stephens from the Bethan and Huw show in Wales, Ras Kwame from 100% Homegrown on 1Xtra, and Rob Da Bank from The Blue Room.
Radio 1 aims to maintain Peel's unpredictable music style under the OneMusic banner but acknowledges the challenge of preserving his legacy.
Sara Cox returns to host the lunchtime show on Saturdays after maternity leave.

Despite the new lineup, some express hope that these DJs will not fully replace Peel's impact, while others appreciate the continuation of his musical diversity and potential for international exposure under the One World name.
The text also suggests considering talent from internet radio stations to emulate Peel's influence.
